questions.text: All are risk factors for Ca breast except?
questions.solution:
• Nulliparity is a risk factor, not multiparity.
  • Schwartz writes-
  • Increased exposure to estrogen is associated with an increased risk for developing breast cancer, whereas reducing exposure is thought to be protective.
  • Correspondingly, factors that increase the number of menstrual cycles, and thus exposure to estrogen, are associated with an increased risk. These are:

Early menarche - Nulliparity  - Late menopause

There is an association between obesity and increased breast cancer risk. Because the major source of estrogen in postmenopausal women is the conversion of androstenedione to estrone by adipose tissue, obesity is associated with increased exposure to estrogen.

choices.text: Lower inner quadrant of breast primary carcinoma.

questions.text: Patients not suitable for sentinel lymph node (SLN) biopsy include all of the following except?
questions.solution: Clinical situations where sentinel lymph node (SLN) dissection is not recommended include patients with inflammatory breast cancers, those with palpable axillary lymphadenopathy and biopsy-proven metastasis, DCIS without mastectomy, or prior axillary surgery. Although limited data are available, SLN dissection appears to be safe in pregnancy when performed with radioisotope alone

questions.text: A 25 year old Female complains of discharge of blood from a single duct in her breast. The most appropriate treatment is?
questions.solution: CSDT writes - 'Unilateral, spontaneous, serious or serosanguineous discharge from a single duct is usually caused by an intraductal papilloma or rarely, by intraductal cancer.' Mostly the underlying cause is a duct papilloma or duct ectasia, but since the chances of malignancy are high, it must be investigated further. the risk of malignancy increases if an underlying mass is present. Investigation used are Mammography - can show any underlying suspicious lesion Cytological examination - this may identify malignant cells, but a negative finding does not rule out cancer. Galactography/Ductography The primary indication for ductography is nipple discharge, particularly when bloody. Ductography though helpful in reaching a diagnosis is not essential since excision of the bloody duct system is indicated regardless of finding. In this study, a contrast medium is injected into the discharging duct and a mammogram taken. The injected may show an intraductal papilloma as a filling defect surrounded by contrast. Cancers may appear as irregular masses or as multiple intraluminal filling defects, or abrupt obstruction. Duct ectasia or fibrocystic disease may appear as dilated cystic structures Ultrasound - may show the presence of an underlying mass or duct ectasia. The final diagnosis is made by excising the involved duct (Microdochotomy) and any underlying mass if present and subjecting them for a histopathological diagnosis. Radical duct excision (meaning removal of all lacticiferous ducts) is not done.

questions.text: Inversion of nipple occurs due to the involvement of ?
questions.solution:
Breast carcinoma arising from lactiferous ducts is called as ductal carcinoma.

  • Breast carcinoma arising from lobules is called as lobular carcinoma. It is 10% common.

Cutaneous Manifestations of Carcinoma Breast

  • Peau d - orange: Due to obstruction of dermal lymphatics, openings of the sebaceous glands and hair follicles get buried in oedema giving rise to orange peel appearance.
  • Dimpling of skin due to infiltration of ligament of Cooper.
  • Retraction of nipple due to infiltration of lactiferous duct.
  • Ulceration, discharge from the nipple and areola.
  • Skin ulceration and function.

Cancer-en-cuirasse: Skin over the chest wall and breast is studded with cancer nodules appearing like an armour coat

questions.text: The common presentation of duct papilloma of the breast is?
questions.solution:
• True polyps of epithelium lined breast ducts Benign and not precancerous Solitary and located under areola Less than 1 cm in size and can grow up to 4-5 cms Most common presentation is bloody nipple discharge
  • Treatment - excision of duct along with tumor known as duct excision

choices.text: Invasion of skin with malignant cells

questions.text: Peau d's orange is due to ?
questions.solution: Peaud's orange is produced due to obstruction of superficial lymph vessels by cancer cells. This causes edema of the skin giving rise to an appearance like that of the skin of an orange (Peaud's orange appearance)

questions.text: FNAC is useful in all the following types of thyroid carcinoma except ?
questions.solution:
• 'FNAC biopsy is unable to distinguish benign follicular lesions from follicular carcinoma. Therefore, preoperative diagnosis of cancer is difficult unless distant metastases are present. Large follicular tumors (> 4 cm) in older men are more likely to be malignant.' - Schwartz Surgery
  • FNAC is the investigation of choice for solitary thyroid nodules.
  • It cannot distinguish between a Follicular Adenoma and a Follicular Carcinoma as this distinction is dependent not on cytology but on histological criteria such as capsular and vascular invasion. It thus cannot be used to diagnose follicular carcinomas.

Note here that -

The criteria for vascular invasion is applicable only for capsular vessels and vessels outside the capsule. the presence of tumor plugs within intratumoral blood vessels has little prognostic significance

questions.text: In which of the following types of breast carcinoma, would you consider biopsy of opposite breast?
questions.solution:
• 'LCIS(lobular Ca in situ)occurs bilaterally in 50 to 70% of cases, while DCIS occurs bilaterally in 10 to 20% of cases' - Schwartz
  • 'Invasive lobular Cais frequently multifocal, multicentric and bilateral.' –Schwartz

questions.text: Arrange the following types of carcinoma in the order of best to worse prognosis: 1) Medullary carcinoma 2) Tubular carcinoma 3) Invasive ductal carcinoma 4) Inflammatory carcinoma
questions.solution:
Tubular carcinoma has the best prognosis. Inflammatory carcinoma has the worst prognosis. Medullary carcinoma has a better prognosis compared to invasive ductal carcinoma.

Order of breast carcinoma from worst to best prognosis:

  • Inflammatory carcinoma breast (Worst prognosis)
  • Invasive ductal carcinoma
  • Invasive lobular carcinoma
  • Medullary carcinoma
  • Colloid carcinoma
  • Papillary carcinoma
  • Cribriform carcinoma
  • Adenocystic

Tubular carcinoma (Best prognosis)

choices.text: Better than mucinous carcinoma of breast
Best among all the types of breast carcinomas
Moderately better compared to other invasive carcinomas
Worst among all the types of breast carcinomas

questions.text: The prognosis of Inflammatory breast carcinoma is?
questions.solution:
The prognosis of inflammatory breast carcinoma is worst among all the types of breast carcinomas.

Inflammatory carcinoma:

Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage IVD) accounts for <3% of breast cancers.

Clinical features:

  • It is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud's orange).
  • There may be an associated breast mass.

Pathologic hallmark: Permeation of the dermal lymph vessels by cancer cells is seen in skin biopsy specimens.

Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

Treatment:

Combined-modality treatment, including neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, and radiation therapy, with hormonal therapy for ER-positive tumors and trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors

choices.text: Papillary growth pattern within duct lumina
Distension and destruction of terminal duct lobular units

questions.text: Which of the following is not a histological feature of Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS)?
questions.solution:
Papillary growth pattern within duct lumina is a feature of Ductal carcinoma in situ.

Histological features of Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS):

  • LCIS originates from the terminal duct lobular unitsand is characterized by distention and distortion of the terminal duct lobular units.
  • Cytoplasmic mucoid globules(Signet ring cell) are a distinctive cellular feature.
  • Neighborhood calcification:  LCIS may be observed in breast tissues that contain microcalcifications, but the calcifications associated with LCIS typically occur in adjacent tissues. This neighborhood calcification is a feature that is unique to LCIS and contributes to its diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following structure is not removed in Patey's modified radical mastectomy?
questions.solution:
Pectoralis major is not removed in Patey's modified radical mastectomy.

A modified radical ('Patey') mastectomy removes:

  • All breast tissue
  • Nipple-areola complex
  • Skin
  • Levels I, II and III axillary lymph nodes
  • Pectoralis minor

Important surgeries for breast cancer:

Breast conservative surgery is also known as segmental mastectomy, lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, wide local excision, and tylectomy.

  • Tylectomy- Excision of lump
  • Simple mastectomy- Palpable extent of breast + overlying skin.
  • Subcutaneous mastectomy - Palpable extent of breast without overlying skin.
  • Total mastectomy- All breast tissue + Nipple-areola complex + skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy - Simple mastectomy +removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Modified radical mastectomy - Entire breast tissue + Nipple areola complex + skin + Axillary lymph nodes (Level I + II - III)
    • Patey's - Pectoralis minor removed
    • Scanlon's Pectoralis minor divided
    • Auchincloss - Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted's radical mastectomy- Entire breast tissue + Nipple areola complex + skin + Level I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted's + Internal mammary lymph nodes
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iversion) mastectomy - Halsted's + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular lymph nodes

Super radical mastectomy - Halsted's + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular + Mediastinal lymph nodes

questions.text: The most commonly used flap for breast reconstruction is?
questions.solution: At the present time, the gold standard in breast reconstruction with autogenous tissue is the transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap because lower abdominal tissues are similar in consistency to breast tissue

questions.text: Van Nuys grading system for Ductal Carcinoma In Situ does not include?
questions.solution:
DCIS is classified using the Van Nuys system, which combines the patient's age, type of DCIS (histologic variant-based on nuclear grade and necrosis) and presence of microcalcification, extent of resection margin and size of disease. Patients with a high score benefit from radiotherapy after excision, whereas those of low grade, whose tumor is completely excised, need no further treatment.

Staining of estrogen and progesterone receptors is now considered routine, as their presence will indicate the use of adjuvant hormonal therapy with tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor. This is not part of the Van Nuys system

questions.text: Physiological gynaecomastia occurs in ?
questions.solution:
Physiologic gynaecomastia usually occurs during three phases of life:

  • Neonatal period
  • Adolescence
  • Senescence

Common to each of these phases is an excess of circulating estrogens in relation to circulating testosterone. Neonatal gynecomastia is caused by the action of placental estrogens on neonatal breast tissues. In adolescence, there is an excess of estradiol relative to testosterone. In senescence, the circulating testosterone level falls, resulting in relative hyperestrinism.

choices.text: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected

questions.text: A female patient presents with breast abscess. Under antibiotic cover aspiration was attempted which failed to reveal any aspirate. The next step in management is?
questions.solution:
• The latest guidelines for management of breast abscess specify that at least two aspirationsshould be attempted before an incision and drainage is done.
  • These aspirations should be made under antibiotic cover. This often allows resolution without the need for an incision scar and also allows the patient to carry on breastfeeding.

A non-healing breast abscess should arouse the suspicion of either tuberculosis of breast or Inflammatory carcinoma of breast

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a family history of breast carcinoma presented to the OPD with a normal mammography report. The next investigation of choice to evaluate for breast disease would be ?
questions.solution:
• MRIis helpful in screening of high risk individuals and it is the most sensitive imaging modality. But it should be done after initial radiological evaluation in which the results may be inconclusive.
  • Here the patient is a high risk individual since there is family history of breast carcinoma.
  • Hence MRI is done after initial radiological evaluation (USG/mammogram) to confirm presence or absence of malignant changes.

Trucut biopsy is the next step following MRI.

questions.text: The best imaging to assess the breast of patients with implants is?
questions.solution:
MRI is the best imaging modality for the breasts of women with implants.

  • MRI is the investigation of choice to screen high risk individuals.
  • It is useful in assessing loco regional spread (multifocality and multicentricity) of carcinoma.

Can distinguish scar from recurrence .

questions.text: Lesions with malignant potential include all of the following except?
questions.solution: Sclerosing adenosis is prevalent during the childbearing and perimenopausal years and has no malignant potential. Multiple intraductal papillomas, which occur in younger women and are less frequently associated with nipple discharge, are susceptible to malignant transformation. Individuals with a diagnosis of atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) are at increased risk for development of breast cancer and should be counseled appropriately regarding risk reduction strategies. Atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH) results in minimal distention of lobular units with cells that are similar to those seen in lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS).

choices.text: MTP followed by treatment according to protocol

questions.text: Treatment of breast cancer with pregnant lady in first trimester ?
questions.solution:
1st trimester
MRM (modified radical mastectomy)
If axillary node is +ve then pregnancy is terminated; (MTP), chemotherapy is given

Second trimester;

MRM,Chemotherapy carefully

Third trimester;

MRM, After delivery, chemotherapy with suppression of lactation

questions.text: Not true about gynaecomastia is ?
questions.solution:
Gynaecomastia is hypertrophy of male breast more than usual due to increase in ductal (epithelial) and connective tissue (stromal) elements often attaining features of the female breast.

It can be unilateral or bilateral. Bilateral can be symmetrical or asymmetrical.

Etiology is 

Oestrogen excess increased estradiol secretion due to a testicular tumor (Leydig cell) or nontesticular tumours from the adrenal cortex, lung, liver; hyperthyroidism (increases conversion of androgen to estrogen), liver diseases, oestrogen therapy for prostate cancer.

Androgen deficiency-aging, Klinefelter's/Kallmann syndromes, a eunuch, ACTH deficiency. 

Secondary testicular failure-cryptorchidism, orchitis, trauma, CRF, etc. 

Drugs (25%): Increases estrogen activity (digitalis, anabolic steroid)/estrogen synthesis (reserpine, theophylline, frusemide).

Inhibition of testosterone synthesis-cimetidine, phenytoin, spironolactone

choices.text: Recurrence of cancer in the ipsilateral breast
Greater chance of breast cancer mortality

questions.text: Failure to perform radiation after wide excision of an invasive cancer risk which of the following outcomes ?
questions.solution: Retrospective reviews and prospective surgical trials agree that omission of breast radiation after wide excision leads to a higher rate of ipsilateral breast recurrence. However, survival and the risk of distant disease are not altered in patients treated by excision alone, within the follow-up time of the studies and given their inherent power to detect differences in outcome. Regional node metastasis is not affected by the choice of mastectomy versus wide excision and radiation.

questions.text: The tumour, which may occur in the residual breast or overlying skin following wide local excision and radiotherapy for mammary carcinoma is ?
questions.solution:
• Angiosarcoma is a vascular tumor which may arise de novo in the breast or as a complication of the radiation therapy.
  • Sabiston writes - 'This vascular tumor may occur de novo in the breast, but the clinically important presentation is in the Dennis after breast radiation or in the lymphedematous upper extremity, following radical mastectomy.'

questions.text: Drugs useful in breast cancer prevention include all of the following except?
questions.solution: The P-2 trial, the Study of Tamoxifen and Raloxifene (known as the STAR trial), randomly assigned 19,747 postmenopausal women at high risk for breast cancer to receive either tamoxifen or raloxifene. The initial report of the P-2 trial showed the two agents were nearly identical in their ability to reduce breast cancer risk, but raloxifene was associated with a more favorable adverse event profile. An updated analysis revealed that raloxifene maintained 76% of the efficacy of tamoxifen in prevention of invasive breast cancer with a more favorable side-effect profile. Aromatase inhibitors (AIs) have been shown to be more effective than tamoxifen in reducing the incidence of contralateral breast cancers in postmenopausal women receiving AIs for adjuvant treatment of invasive breast cancer.

choices.text: Follicular carcinoma thyroid with metastatic lymph nodes

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a painless lymph node in the cervical region. Lymph node biopsy showed normal thyroid gland features. The thyroid is normal on palpation clinically. The diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
Thyroid tissue present in cervical lymph nodes in the face of a clinically normal thyroid gland is a metastasis from an occult primary thyroid carcinoma

Occasionally, a metastatic papillary thyroid cancer manifests as a painless lateral neck mass that is clinically detected before detecting the primary thyroid lesion.

Comment: Normal thyroid tissue is a trap by the examiner, remember in young people papillary thyroid cancer mostly is well differentiated.

Well, differentiated cells look like normal cells and tend to grow .and spread more slowly than poorly differentiated cells (anaplastic carcinoma).

choices.text: Urinary catecholomine and aspiration of nodule

questions.text: Investigation of choice in case of a pt. with episodic hypertension, headache and thyroid nodule ?
questions.solution:
• This pt is having MEN type II syndrome which is characterized by
  • Phaeochromocytoma and
  • Medullary carcinoma of thyroid (MCT)
  • Urinary catecholamines are increased in phaeochromocytoma
  • Aspiration of nodule will show amyloid material (seen in MCT)

choices.text: Extensive DCIS should be treated with tamoxifen followed by lumpectomy.
Postoperative tamoxifen is useful in DCIS patients whose tumors are estrogen-receptor (ER) negative.
Specimen mammography is only useful for patients with small amounts of DCIS.
DCIS treated by mastectomy has a local recurrence rate of <2%.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the management of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is true?
questions.solution: Women with DCIS and evidence of extensive disease (>4 cm of disease or disease in more than one quadrant) usually require mastectomy. For women with limited disease, lumpectomy and radiation therapy are generally recommended. For nonpalpable DCIS, needle localization or other image-guided techniques are used to guide the surgical resection. Specimen mammography is performed to ensure that all visible evidence of cancer is excised. Adjuvant tamoxifen therapy is considered for DCIS patients with estrogen-receptor (ER)-positive disease. The gold standard against which breast conservation therapy for DCIS is evaluated is mastectomy Women treated with mastectomy have local recurrence and mortality rates of <2%.

questions.text: Which of the following test is unable to differentiate between 'in situ' breast cancer and invasive disease ?
questions.solution:
• FNAC is the least invasive technique for obtaining a cell diagnosis and is very accurate if both operator and cytologists are experienced.
  • However false negatives do occur, mainly through sampling error, and invasive cancer cannot be distinguished from 'in situ' disease.
  • A histological specimen taken by core biopsy allows a definitive preoperative diagnosis, differentiates between duct carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and invasive disease and also allows the tumor to be stained for receptor status.
  • This is important before commencing neoadjuvant therapy. Bailey and Love

questions.text: Aromatase inhibitors are used in the treatment of?
questions.solution:
Aromatase inhibitors are used in the treatment of breast cancer

Hormonal therapy for Breast Ca:

  • Tamoxifen is the most widely used hormonal treatment in Ca breast.
  • Effect of tamoxifen is favourable in cases with estrogen receptor (ER-positive disease).
  • LHRH agonists which induce a reversible ovarian suppression. Have same beneficial effects as surgical or radiation-induced ovarian ablation in premenopausal receptor positive women.
  • Oral aromatase inhibitors 

Nonsteroidal

Letrozole

It is an orally active non steroidal compound that reverses aromatization all over the body including that within the breast cancer cell resulting in total estrogen deprivation It is used in early breast cancer as an adjuvant therapy after mastectomy in ER-positive cases and it is also used for postmenopausal women for recurrent breast Ca (superior to tamoxifen) Anastrazole is another non steroidal aromatase inhibitor which is more potent than Letrozole and suitable for single daily dosing. Exemestane is a steroidal orally acting aromatase inhibitor

choices.text: Grade 3, poorly differentiated, infiltrating ductal carcinoma
Positive surgical margin for invasive cancer
Extensive intraductal cancer around the invasive lesion

questions.text: Which of the following pathologic findings is the strongest contraindication to breast preservation (lumpectomy with breast radiation) as primary treatment for a newly diagnosed breast cancer ?
questions.solution: The only firm contraindication to wide excision and radiation (breast preservation, lumpectomy) as the primary surgical treatment for a newly discovered breast cancer is the inability to achieve an uninvolved surgical margin after excision of the tumor. A positive surgical margin requires, at least, reoperation with an attempt at re-excision of cancer. If the margin of removal is positive after attempts at re-excision, this is a strong reason to recommend mastectomy in preference to breast conservation. Tumor size is a relative contraindication when the cancer is so large in relation to the breast that excision to a clean surgical margin seems unreasonable. Other histologic findings, such as tumor grade or vascular invasion, are not strong reasons to recommend a mastectomy if the patient would prefer breast conservation.
